title: Domain structure of proteins set member 1

content.description:
Figure 1. Domain structure of two proteins

Investigators studied the interactions between two different proteins, protein <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and protein <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">II</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>. Each protein has two structural domains (Figure 1) that represent different functional parts of the protein. Different combinations of the protein domains were tested for their ability to bind to a known DNA sequence, interact with each other, and activate transcription. The results are shown in Table 1.

TABLE 1. INTERACTION AND FUNCTION OF COMBINATIONS OF STRUCTURAL VARIANTS OF PROTEINS <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mtext>I</mtext></math> AND <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mtext>II</mtext></math>

content.question: Which of the following claims is best supported by the data from test <math alttext="5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn></math> in Table 1 ?

choices.label: Domain <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>L</mtext></math> is required for transcription activation.

Domain <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is not required for protein-protein interaction.
Protein-protein interaction is necessary for DNA binding.
Protein-protein interaction is sufficient for transcription activation.

content.answer: Domain <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is not required for protein-protein interaction.
